description.text:
This is a mount for the SQ11 HD camera. It should also work for the SQ8 and SQ10 models as well as other similarly shaped cameras.

https://www.amazon.com/dp/B072N74SQW/
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0719Q1X7S/
https://www.eyespysupply.com/micro-cube-cam-mini-spy-camera-motion-activated-night-vision.html.

It's intended to be mounted onto a mini quadcopter using a velcro strap or zip ties.

It's been designed using OpenSCAD, and the source code is included. It's somewhat parametric, allowing you to change things like the tilt angle relatively easily, but I got impatient towards the end and hard-coded certain things for the 30° angle I was after. You might have to tweak some of those hard-coded values if you intend to make modifications.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I've tried printing this in two different orientations, with the wedge at the bottom facing down, and with the back side of the camera mount facing down. Both seemed to work fairly well.

There's a few overhangs, but the model can still be printed without supports if you're not after absolutely perfect but still entirely functional results. If you decide to print with supports, orienting the part with the back side facing down towards the print bed will require less material and will make support removal easier as well.

Remove supports if you chose to print with them.

Depending on the elasticity of your filament, the fit might be a bit tight. You can make small cuts to one or two corners in the back to give yourself some more room to push in the camera. Even with those cuts everything seems to be held in place fairly well.

comments.text:
How about splitting this up so it's actually printable?
If you cut the model into 4 parts, the top shell, the bottom shell and 2 halves for the white surround it could be assembled with very little visible seam.
The 2 halves of the white ring around the shell could probably print as /\ shaped arches on most printers without overhang issues. These would obscure the seam between the two halves of the shell and could even be used to hold it together. A small lip on the flat edge of the 2 halves of the shell combined with a groove on the inside of the white ring would allow the whole thing to clip together nicely and be fixed with just 2 dots of glue, one on each side of the outer ring arches.

title: More Designs for C3xor's Interchangable Stamp System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My mum's a potter so I thought it would be a good idea to design some stamps for her birthday. I came across C3xor's system and I liked the concept so I went with that. I found some free designs I thought would work well and turned them into stamps.

For each stamp print a copy of "stamp parts" and your "stamp design" and as many handles you need total (they swap out between the stamps).

Refer to C3xor's thing for assembly.

Please note that I had trouble with handles breaking at 20% infill so you should probably make sure the infill's higher than that. I also had to do a bunch of cleanup with an exacto knife of the stamp designs so unless your printer is godlike or you're willing to fix it up I'd probably go for the simpler ones like 2 and 10.

I figured out the dimensions for the stamp head provided using Mesh Mixer and modeled it in Fusion 360 (30mm diameter cylinder that's 5mm tall with a 3mm deep 15.2 mm diameter cylindrical hole in the bottom, with the design 3.45mm above the base to make a total height of 8.45mm.) I inserted the .svg files I found and extruded up to the desired height.

References

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Borromean_interlaced_torcs_Wayland_knot.svg - (8)

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Faith_Buddhism_Endless_Knot_3_v2.svg - (10)

https://openclipart.org/detail/259988/square-ornament-19 From a drawing in 'Histoire de Saint-Bonnet-le-Chateau', James Condamin, 1885. - (1)

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Circle_Celtic_Ornament_1.svg - (11)

https://openclipart.org/detail/234087/celtic-ornament-v4 - (13)

title: TARDIS Deluxe New Rear Panel for Raspberry Pi Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to use this as a Raspberry Pi case for a specific purpose, but getting the (many) cables in was a problem. So I redid a side panel to make it easier to run the cables to the Pi. I also wanted a little more room, so I printed the entire project at 140%. I drilled the mounting holes for the Pi by hand, in one of the side panels.

The specific purpose was to mount the Pi in a case that suited the program I was running. It is an Amiga Emulator, and for me, the ability to run and program an Amiga is, in itself, a time machine. Hence the TARDIS, to help take me back to the 80s.

Not content with just having it sit there, I decided to activate it while loading up the emulator. I added two LEDs, a white one for the beacon, and an amber one one for the interior light. I also plugged in a cheap PC speaker for sound.

I then intercepted the Amiga Emulator startup and wrote a program to turn on the interior LED and pulse the beacon. I used a Linux program called aplay to play the TARDIS sound.

countspatula included labels, but since I don't have a label maker, I was stuck with using JPGs, which get a little ragged when scaled up to 140%. So I made my own, using Corel Draw. I printed them on Avery labels (5523/5543 - same as 5163) because the weaherproof labels are much whiter than regular paper or labels. I have uploaded the Corel file.

I have posted a video of it in action on YouTube:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7HkrkMe3UTE

print_settings.Notes:: Print the bracket with FPV ring down on your print surface. If you print it in any orientation, the ring will be much weaker and may shear off because the "grain" of the printer will not be laid in an optimal direction. Be careful when removing supports in the FPV wire conduit, use tweezers to break off small sections and a thin screwdriver if needed to break off supports. I used 60 degree supports everywhere and it wasn't too bad of a cleanup job. Controller board bracket is printed with the back of the motor down on the print surface. Top bracket is printed just as it is shown in the preview above. I did 60 degrees initial layer and 50 the rest of the way with 200 degrees using red PLA, worked for me, but you know your printer and PLA better than I do so do what you've had good results with. Sliced in Cura

title: F450 F550 Style Multicopter GoPro SJCam FPV Gimbal
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original design was a good starting point, but it was essentially a duplication of the aluminum frames that are being sold with gimbal kits, so I decided to take it a step further. My previous frame had an aluminum frame that had an fpv camera zip tied to the bottom with wires everywhere. The velcro piece that held the camera on was so annoying and blocked most of the camera buttons and the screen, and there were many other issues that I tried to address. By no means is this design perfect, but it's an improvement over the popular original aluminum frames that are out there

  1. Add FPV camera ring underneath your HD action cam so you can actually see what you're shooting without having to use wifi on your camera, and so that you can have a stabilized FPV image. Wiring for FPV camera goes through conduit so that it does not interfere with gimbal operation
  2. Instead of having double sided tape holding your gyro/accelerometer to the gimbal, there is a pocket with screw holes that will secure and protect the board so that components don't break off on hard landings or crashes
  3. Middle bracket shape is changed to allow for pointing straight down while hovering, original style frame does not allow for straight down shooting without tangling up wires
  4. Combine controller board and top arm so that you don't need screws holding them together
  5. Combine top board with dampened 10mm rod brackets so that you no longer need aluminum brackets and adapters to hold your on 10mm rods
  6. Add an On/Off switch so that you can turn off your gimbal when you are doing things like calibrating your magnetometer and accelerometer (which requires flipping your multicopter around in all directions while powered on, which can fry your BGC board)
  7. Add a hard stop for middle bracket to prevent it from flipping over and tangling up your wires
  8. Remove as much material as possible without making the frame weak to reduce weight

Some things you may need:

  • Mini FPV camera - http://amzn.to/2lSRLXk or similar
  • Action cam GoPro or SJCam or any of the clones that are all the same size
  • A landing system that uses 10mm tubes - http://amzn.to/2CjLDPb or similar
  • Some thin silicone wire for FTP camera wiring - http://amzn.to/2CA5SMr or similar
  • A cheap aluminum frame 2 axis gimbal - http://amzn.to/2CwGCWK or similar
  • Mini switches - http://amzn.to/2EPitZZ or similar

This build reuses rubber dampeners from landing gear and gimbal kits, so be sure to get the ones similar to links above if you don't want to buy any extra parts

Yeah, that's an IR blocked zoom lens with a UV filter on a $30 sjcam7000 clone, works great!! I use a fisheye for my FPV, most people like a normal lens but I like having a wide field of view when I'm flying FPV. I bought my own 10mm rods, the rods that most of these kits come with are very fragile, are too thick and heavy

I'm also working on a landing system based on this one that uses standard size carbon fiber rods and all 3d printed parts, with a modular battery box, adjustable center of gravity, and a mount for an F450/F550 style multicopter that's cleaner than using zip-ties or whatever these kits usually call for... so stay tuned!!

UPDATE #1: this gimbal with motors, fpv camera, and motors is lighter than the old aluminum brackets without any components!

UPDATE #2: Now included are 3 new files for V2 direct mount top bracket. This is if you use a different type of landing system or don't have rubber bushings for the top brackets. The dampers for bottom plate are cheap and easy to find, but the top rubber bushings are nearly impossible to find and they aren't really needed. So V2 addresses this issue since you can now use this system without those bushings, and since you're already using dampers for bottom plate, there is no need for them. This also makes it a lot easier to remove and install the gimbal for maintenance or if you want to fly without it. I also moved the switch behind the plate so that it is more protected between the two 10MM tubes instead of being on the side

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Print the bracket with FPV ring down on your print surface. If you print it in any orientation, the ring will be much weaker and may shear off because the "grain" of the printer will not be laid in an optimal direction. Be careful when removing supports in the FPV wire conduit, use tweezers to break off small sections and a thin screwdriver if needed to break off supports. I used 60 degree supports everywhere and it wasn't too bad of a cleanup job. Controller board bracket is printed with the back of the motor down on the print surface. Top bracket is printed just as it is shown in the preview above. I did 60 degrees initial layer and 50 the rest of the way with 200 degrees using red PLA, worked for me, but you know your printer and PLA better than I do so do what you've had good results with. print_settings.Notes:: Be sure to print the parts the right way up to avoid using supports, and keep that part cooling fan on so as to avoid curled edges on the overhangs.

description.text:
First off, let me please ask that if you like these designs and find them useful please do like, follow and share my content. And if you have any ideas or concepts to modify the content I would love to hear!

Also, a shoutout to all the filament cleaners out there keeping all our 1.75mm and 3mm filaments clean and our nozzles jam free since they first started popping up.

I have been playing with threads lately and wanted to adapt what I was producing to the pre-existing concept. You have two parts, you cut a chunk of foam that will fit snuggly in the cavity and then you screw them together nice and tight, slip your 1.75mm or 3mm filament through the orifice and out the opposing and let it pull up tight against your extruders input. It can go either way on your printers filament, though it has to have the filament poked through it, so get ready to retract your plastic to put this on. If I get there for a V2 I will amend it so it can be placed onto the filament without having to thread it through the assembly.

Take it and do with it what you wish. For me it works really well. And again a shoutout to the others that are producing these things, especially the ever so popular https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:492067

It is designed lightly, so be sure to follow the print instructions and print a 0.4mm wall thickness with a decent infill. I use 28% infill (my lucky number). Be sure to print the parts the right way up to avoid using supports, and keep that part cooling fan on so as to avoid curled edges on the overhangs.

title: Module conversion for hitec / futaba radio

description.text:
An interface to install JR type modules on Futaba /Hitec style radios. With this you can use for instance the last FrSky XJT module or a 433Mhz long range module designed for JR / Taranis / Turnigy radios.
I tested this interface on a Hitec Aurora trasmitter with succes. It's only necessary to build an interface cable made from dupont cables in order to supply Vcc, ground and PPM signal.

Here is my personal add-on to two works from toemat and from dmyers7, I only added an interface block that connects the two modules and remixed Aurora module with longer strips in order to facilitate extraction.

This work is made of three parts, a dummy module for futaba/hitech bay, an interface block to connect futaba/hitech module to JR case bymeans of three M3 screws - so it's removable - and JR case itself.
JR case shall be glued (epoxy) in final position on the interface block after check for interferences. I preferred to rotate 90° clockwise for clearance and module extraction, so my antenna lies horizontally.

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 mk2 - Fan Duct Improved

title: Prusa MK2 Better Part Cooling Fan Duct with support

description.text:
I've been printing a lot with PETG which is what my hotend parts are made from, and this is causing the screws nearest the hotend to heat up. The screw closest to the hotend is actually for the part cooling fan, but because I'm printing PETG that doesn't use much cooling, it is starting to sag since it isn't cooling itself down natually and it has no counter support on the other side of the part (just an alignment pin). It was sagging to the point where it was 1-2mm from hitting the model I was printing, and causing extra stringing due to the mis-aimed air that was pointing at the nozzle instead of the part.

This part solves this problem by giving the part cooling fan an extra point of support that is far away from the hotend, and thus keeping the part cooling fan level and out of range from hitting your model.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed in PETG, but always print in high temp filament for the pieces around the hotend (like ABS or PETG)

All Prusa MK2/S use the rotary blower fan, but these parts are subject to change due to supplier. My original model was based on this in CAD, and then was just 1mm taller in reality, so I've adjusted the model to reflect this, but the STL is of the original part. You may need to drill out the holes for the screws at the top and bottom using a 3mm bit, or closest Imperial equivalent.

description.text: Vertical Savonius wind turbine is fitted to bottom supporting system. Power will depend of print scale. The original will be probably around 20-50W

Variometer with mechanical needle and LCD for use with Openvario. Can also be used for simulators. Work in progress.

This is a standard 60x60mm instrument (57mm diameter hole). Its designed around the x27.168 automotive gauge stepper motor, a rotary encoder (Keyes 040 for now) and one of these two displays:

  • 1.3" SHARP Memory LCD.
  • 1.54" Waveshare E-ink display

Both displays are are perfectly sunlight readable, but have no backlight. Cockpit sim builders may want to use an OLED instead, and will have to modify the design.

The eink displays looks a little better, is larger and has a higher resolution; but the update rate is slow, on the order of 2 frames per second.

This 5V stepper can be driven directly from an arduino, but for smoother movement, I recommend you use a microstepper controller like the AX1201728SG. More info here:
https://guy.carpenter.id.au/gaugette/2017/04/29/switecx25-quad-driver-tests/

For use with Openvario, the code is still being worked on, you can follow this project here:
https://forum.xcsoar.org/viewtopic.php?f=30&t=3062

I will modify the design to hold the electronics later once I settled on the components. For now, you'll have house them externally or make something yourself.

The 3 main bolts are M4 sized and friction fit for now. For the encoder, also use M4 bolt or a smooth shaft. 2 M3 bolts are used to hold modules together during assembly.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Installing the needle is a little tricky after the LCD is mounted. Test mount before installing the LCD and use pliers and patience. Make sure the needle doesnt touch anything and moves completely smoothly.

You can print the faceplate I provided on photo paper, and use a circle cutter or exquisite scissor skills to cut it out. Use a very sharp knife to cut out the LCD. I have no idea yet how this will cope with sunlight; maybe use some UV protection spray?

title: F550 iNav CleanFlight BetaFlight external compass MAG3110 Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I use MAG3110 compass module for the following reasons:

  1. Integrated compasses that come with most flight controllers are completely useless because a flight controller is normally surrounded by wires that have some serious amperage going through them (aka electromagnets)
  2. MAG3110 works with boards that have integrated compasses unlike HMC5983 because you cannot have more than one HMC5983 on the same i2c bus. So if you have a board with HMC5983 unless you physically break off connectors to it, you cannot use an external one
  3. Since I2C is a BUS, you can hook up multiple I2C devices to the same connector, so you do not have to waste a port on a compass if you use MAG3110 like this:
    http://amzn.to/2lPPWur

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

I unsoldered the connectors that came with the board and soldered them to the bottom of the board, so they can be pointing downwards through the bottom bracket. Then you can use DuPont connectors to connect the board to your flight controller and the other side to whatever other i2c device you're using, I'm using an lcd display to view information about flight controller, satellites, compass, and other settings without having to drag a laptop everywhere I fly. If you use iNav, you can trim your board in the field using a display mod without having to hook up laptop or tablet to your flight controller by just using the radio. The board will fit in this case without moving connectors, but then they will stick out and wires may get close to the props, so this way it is a much cleaner installation. "MAG3110" text won't print, cura engine can't handle it, but the N on the arrow will work. This is meant to go on the #2 motor arm of an F550, it will point in the wrong direction if mounted on any other arm or if used on an F450. If you need a modified version, let me know and I can easily put one together with a different angle

If you're wondering about those corncob LEDs, they're for FAA dusk/dawn light requirement, I used cheap turn signal LEDs you can get them dirt cheap and they're easy to take apart (just heat up the metal part with a blow torch until LED assembly falls out) They are WAY brighter than needed for the 2 mile visibility requirement and much cheaper than all the packaged solutions

description.text:
Hi all,

this is my personal version of the Geeetech prusa I3X acrylic, named MK2. I used some parts found on thingiverse and I've adapted it to my needs. other parts was my personal design.
The Z carriage were taken from this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1103976, while the strap tensioner and endstop are my design.
The Y for Double Filament is my design based on the idea of this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2444687
The support for the 2 extruder motors is my design and has a hinge so that it can be rotated to fit the filament, the bottom of this extruders is designed to fit the pinion so that the filament can be easily inserted.
The extruder X carriage is entirely my design except for the back part, printed from this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:184933. It has a bed leveling probe with an optical switch and a carbon rod, very accurate in the measurement. The fan for cooling the molded part and the fan for the J-head. I inserted 3 leds behind the extruder to light up the printed part.
The printing area has been enlarged using a glass of a 24x30 frame and an heated bed of 216x316 obtained a useful 220 x 260 x 200h printing area.
Extensions for the original Y carriage are my design.
A fan was attached to the chassis frame to cool the GT2560 and finally, the threaded rods are of trapezoidal type with 1mm pitch.

Have fan and a good print!!!!

title: F450 F550 style multicopter iNav OLED LCD Display Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a display holder for the following style OLED LCD displays:
http://amzn.to/2lRi9Bb

This display is I2C so it works with most flight controllers that run iNav. You can use the display to view compass, satellite, battery, and other information without needing a laptop or tablet connected to your multicopter. With iNav, you can also do board trim with an OLED display and your radio in the field without any other devices being connected. If you have a MAG3110 external compass, you can chain this display from it, so you can run both the external compass (for much better compass accuracy) and this display from a single i2c port

See https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2579612

More information about why you'd want to hook up an LCD display to your flight controller
https://github.com/iNavFlight/inav/blob/master/docs/Display.md

title: Anet A8 custom X-idlers (in OpenSCAD)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The OpenSCAD file contains 3 modules to create the X idlers (right and left X-Z mounts) and the X-rods for the Prusa i3 style printers like the Anet A8 or the Hesine M-505.

The reason for this assembly is the development of a new frame with alternative bed size parameters and adaptation to the materials I acquired. In the design you simply specify the outer diameter size of the Z-rod bearing, the tolerance on the X-rod and the length of the rods you bought, the center to center distance between the Z-rods and the center to center distance of the Z-rod to the threaded rod (note that there is also a parameter than extends the left mount, effectively moving the stepper, for frame or electronics box clearance). Also note that there is a boolean operator that can be used to remove/insert screw holes for the trapezoidal nut. This will produce the X-idlers. When calling the modules separately, you will be able to generate the STL files yourself.

Note that you require to make the changes according your own design and check the dimensions beforehand. E.g. all pictures are generated for a z rod thickness of 10 mm, and an increased length for the x rods (450 mm long).

Note that leaving out the trapezoidal screw holes requires the usage of a lifting device that contains the trapezoidal nut. This explains why the trapezoidal nut flange is located at the bottom of this design, this conveniently creates a larger base to rest on the lifting device. The lifting device depicted in the assembly pictures is posted at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2588347. The linear bearings developed with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476782.

This design makes use of 2 libraries, please install them in OpenSCAD:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:871140
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1305888

Anti Z wobble X-idler lifting device

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2588347

IGUS style custom bearings

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476782

description.text:
I created a static coupling for the z-axis. It uses a tight fit to connect it to a nema 17 stepper motor. So you dont need any screw to connect it to your stepper. There is no backlash and my Z-Wobble dissappeared after using this coupling.
On the other side is a 8mm hole for connection to a threaded rod. You can use the coupling for your Prusa i3 or any other 3d-printer. I use it on my custom 3d printer aka Megatron.

I includes the ".step" files and the solidwokrs parts into the download. So you can customize the construction for your individual usecase.

title: F4U Corsair - fuselage test print
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
If you try to print this right now, it will not go together.

Parts are to be printed as flat as possible, orient as appropriate.

I have added in a better-organized zip folder which has my F4U fuselage and partial wing F360 file, as well as all the fuselage parts. I will be starting the test print of the fuselage over the next few days, and put together assembly instructions as I take notes.

The wing has a complete left wing and a centre section. To get the right wing, mirror every single part in the left wing folder. Alignment is done via either lapped joints, recessed tenons, or bamboo skewer (3mm diameter) 10mm long dowels.

Firewall is designed to be printed at 45% infill, and holes are spaced to suit one of my engine mounts. I have another engine mount to measure and design for it.

I am currently reworking the nose section, I will leave the solid front section for those with a better printer but I am making an alternative version as well that my printer and dirt-cheap, terrible filament will be able to produce.

Following feedback, I have started to do work on reworking the wings, both to make them a bit easier to build, as well as providing flaps for increased lift.

This is very much an early work in progress. I don't know if it will print, or if it will even fly. While 3DLabPrint deserve recognition and should be lauded for their methods, I do not like their technique of printing the skin of the aircraft. I am going old school with my building methods.

Balsa builders will recognize my formers, spar and rib designs. The intention is to construct formers with the minimum needed material and cover with a lightweight skin. If you use a heat-resistant plastic, then you may be able to use an iron on film like Monokote. I will be covering with tissue paper, then doping with hairspray, another classic method. If you're feeling really posh, you might be able to use silk, but no idea if that would actually adhere.

non-exhaustive to do list

  • print, assemble and document.
  • wing landing gear attachment method - holes in spar to zip-tie a right-angle bent metal coat hanger.
  • hollow out wing spars with fillets
  • modify rib sketches, fillet corners
  • mirror wing
  • notch wing half mating surfaces
  • notch fuselage formers and spars
  • cut fuselage ribs in half, mirror to get appropriate cuts for left spar
  • split fuselage spars to 150mm printable lengths
  • Turn formers into inner and outer skin with cross supports

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

.25-.32 on .4mm nozzle

Infill:

Gradual infill to 20%, 4 steps.

Notes:

Many parts have very little contact area, so a brim may be necessary.

Step 1

Remove brims, fill and sand as required.

Step 2
  • Sand meeting faces for all the spars.
  • Assemble with superglue or epoxy, clamp.

The spar pieces are named in the order that they should be assembled.

Dieses Objekt ist keine Idee von mir, aber ich wollte testen ob es tatsächlich hilfreich ist.
Für jeden der Schwierigkeiten beim EInstecken von Steckern hat, ist das sicher sehr Praktisch.

Viel Spaß damit :)

Weil Fragen aufgekommen sind, hier die Anleitung:
Diese Objekt wird in die Schuko Steckdose gesteckt und hilft dort, die Kontakte einzufädeln.
Beim ersten einstecken werden die Kontakte des Steckers auf eine Kreisbahn zu den Kontakten der Steckdose gebracht und durch drehen kann die Verbindung dann hergestellt werden. Es hilft bei Sehbehinderten oder Schwer zugänglichen Steckdosen den Stecker richtig einzustecken, sollte aber nicht für dauerhafte Verbindungen benutzt werden.

WICHTIG: KEIN LEITFÄHIGES FILAMENT BENUTZEN - DO NOT USE CONDUCTING FILAMENT

comments.text: No idea what is does, as no description provided. It looks like it should be placed inside the socket. Sitting there it would avoid proper electrical contact between plug and socket, which can result in heat and fire - perfect if you want to burn your place down.
comments.author: MazeMieter

comments.text: if you want to see the original product here it is: http://www.steck-fix.de/
comments.author: MazeMieter

comments.text:
I think that you dont understand german and european plugs perfectly so you cant know what this is for...
so i will explain that for you:
This is a copy of a commerical product that i have seen in television which sits between socket and plug. And no, it dosent prevent electrical contact and the flamability depends on the material you are using. Its meant to help elder people pluggin in by directing the contacts into the holes. This helps to put the contacts into the circle and turning the plug will make the contact. The plug fits firmly due to spring loaded ground connections
comments.author: MazeMieter

comments.text:
What can I possible say...I'll try a quote from Wikipedia (german):
Zum Nachrüsten existieren auch dauerhafte Einsätze, bei welchen man einen Schutz mit dem Stecker wegschiebt oder wegdreht, auch „Kinderschutz-Plättchen“ genannt. Diese verändern aber die Abmessungen der Steckdose, so dass die Kontaktstifte weniger tief eindringen können. Je nach konkreter Konstruktion und Einbausituation können Toleranzen überschritten werden, dadurch auch die Kontaktflächen geringer werden, wodurch ein größerer elektrischer Widerstand entsteht und sich das Stecksystem besonders bei größeren Lasten stark erwärmen kann. Gemäß den österreichischen Bestimmungen für Elektrotechnik ÖVE-IG 31c/1988 dürfen die Abmessungen der Steckvorrichtungen nicht durch nachträglich angebrachte Vorrichtungen verändert werden,[8] wodurch für ein derartiges Produkt in Österreich ein Verbot des Inverkehrbringens ausgesprochen wurde.[9] Auch nach den VDE-Bestimmungen dürfen die Maße nicht verändert werden.[10]
https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schuko#Erh.C3.B6hter_Ber.C3.BChrungsschutz

description.text:
My files for the Giant building block version of Lego Technic model Go-Kart 1972

Files are provided as-is.

Updated 06/11/17: A couple of STL parts were exported incorrectly, These were in the "RED STL PARTS.zip" and "GREY STL Other Parts.zip" files that have now been updated.

STL Files at 1:1 scale, these files have been designed to be scaled five times larger and may work at other scales. Many of the parts are generated from the supplied SCAD files. These SCAD files were my tweaked versions of projunk files. I added fillets to the top of the pins and altered some dimensions / tolerances. Original projunk files can be found here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/projunk/designs

The STL files are zipped up into their various colours. There is a PDF document containing the required quantity of each part. For more information on the original kit and build instructions visit here:

https://www.toysperiod.com/lego-set-reference/technic/model/race/lego-1972-go-cart/

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

Varous

Notes:

Most bricks are printed at 15 to 20% infill.
Axles are printed at 50% infill
Gears and pins at 25% infill
Tyres at 20% infill

Watch the build video for more details on print process.
https://youtu.be/jDz1jJxER-I

comments.text: Well PLA varies but I’ve never gone above 220hot end, 60bed. Try using Cura and one of their PLA profiles, also add a brim of at least 5 perimeters to help adhesion. I presume the print moved on the bed?

comments.text: Not sure why your shouting :O... anyway if the part is not sticking well you may need to adjust your Z offset, I have had to do this on both my Taz6 printers as I found the nozzle was too far away from the bed after auto calibration. on the LCD screen.. Configuration -> Advanced Settings -> Z Offset

comments.text: hi matt pretty good now. see the pics. 2 small issues i have run into are, the adhesion is super good now when i pry the model out 2 of the parts in the back broke off. see the pics please. can i reduce the brim to a 1 or 2. and whats the best way to clean the brim of the model. thanks a lot for all your help. best regards,
comments.author: sathish17110

comments.text: Hi. So your printing in ABS? If so you might have any to raise your hot end temperature as it may be a layer binding issue! Also I use Sinplify3D to slice my models, it only puts the brim on the outer edges of the model, so I can see why it might be an issue here... try reducing the brim, I snap most of mine off then clean up with the edge of a steel Rilee or carefully with a knife.. wear gloves!!

You will only use 2 of the terminals on the harness, the unused terminal will just float disconnected and won't matter. description.text: UbertoothOne is a Bluetooth Spectrum Analyzer.  If purchased assembled it comes as a bare circuit board.  I searched a bit on Thingiverse but could not find something to fit the spec, so why not build my own! This was my first successful 3D print project.  It works best with the clear filament, but we ended up running out.  The back cap fits a little loose but when attached to the USB plug, it stays put.

Using 123D Design Desktop app, I began using sketches (after 3 attempts to just place the 3D objects). I brushed the dust off my geometry skills and created 6 different sketches.
Main box = 13.00mm x 22.52mm sketch
Antenna = 8.00mm diameter circle sketch
Inner box = 10.00mm x 19.52mm sketch
Outer Cap = used Main box sketch
Inner Cap = 8.90mm x 18.42mm sketch
USB = 5.05mm x 12.55mm sketch Extruded the Main box sketch first to 65.25 mm
Placed the inner box sketch centered on the Main Box
Extruded down through the main box 63.50mm for the antenna whole
Centered the antenna sketch and extruded through the bottom of the box.
Placed the out Outer Cap sketch on the plane and extruded that up 2.00mm
Centered the Inner Cap sketch on the Out Cap and extruded up 1.00mm
Centered the USB port on the Inner Cap and Extruded down 4.00mm.
Select the cap and group it so everything moves around the plane easily.
For verification move the cap and flip it to see if it fits the end of the main box. Save your sketches and make sure your objects are flush with the plane. I having issues with the Makerbot where it wasn't printing the cap at the same time as the case and it started to goo up. I was told that the Makerware app should bring everything to equal level but for some reason it didn't see the cap at all. I had to run through Autodesk first then send it to Makerware.

comments.text: Its a little more then a spec analyzer with the right software.
comments.author: anode505

comments.text: Well aware of that.  Still learning how to mess around with it.  Figured I'd keep the full details out as those searching for this thing will already know what the Ubertooth is.  I just hated carrying it around in a static bag :D

description.text: This wedge jack is a larger version with upgraded parts for large area print beds. It should be printed with a higher heat resistant material since it will remain in contact with the bottom of a heated print bed.

Parts need to put this together were all purchased from Lowes:

(x1) 6" 10-24 Threaded Rod
(x2) 10-24 Coupling Nut
(x2) 10-24 Nut
(x1) 10-24 x 1/2 Clamping Knob w/Male Stud

My Creality CR-10 S4 has a bow of maybe 3mm or 4mm in the middle of the print bed. I struggled for over a month to come up with a solution to make the bed level in the middle but it just wouldn't happen. I opted for the cheapest way possible and this is the solution I came up with.

After you print all the parts you may want to grease up the channel and the threads of the screw. This will drastically reduce binding as the nut slides through the channel. The 2 nuts on both ends are super glued on. Be sure all parts are exactly where they need to be and the Wedge works as advertised prior to super gluing the parts

With the print of ABS in mind, I thought of developing a way to prevent the cool air of the hexagon hotend from cooling the print part, and so I developed this fanduct.

After some tests, it's very useful for ABS printing but also improves the finish quality in general.

Micro Delta Rework user's, let's rock !
... a bit more.

Printer:

Micro Delta Rework

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1618

Infill:

0%

Notes:

ABS @ 235Cº / 90Cº
Rafts : use Brim !
Optimized for 0.5mm nozzle with walls @ 0.9mm

Fan screws

Before mounting this fanduct you must mark the position of the fan fixing screws and open a small cavity with a round file so that the fitting is perfect.

I did not make this modification in the 3d model because the walls are very thin and I ran the risk of failing the print.

To couple the fanduct to the fan I used a M3x15mm screw and two nuts.

This is the punisher pod!

This pod is attached with one screw to the rear standoff, and with two m3 nuts and screws in the front.

There is a built in shelf in the pod which is perfect for mounting a frsky xm+ or similar size receiver.

Print this in TPU or similar flexible filament.

After the print is complete and the support is removed, cut off the rear leg. It is only there for stability during the print.

The pod is made for the swift mini fpv camera.

I have also added a factory file with the supports and settings that I use when printing this pod.
For those who do not have Simplify3d, I have also added a gcode file. This gcode/factory file works great on my prusa-style printer.

If you choose to just download the stl, make sure you use plenty of support for best results.

Dont forget to post pictures if you decide to print this :)

title: LWC " CrossBBow" lower Picatinny rail  spring BB shower
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A remix of the " frilled neck FRAG" grenade, but this time it is mounted on your gun.
A more compact design for the cost of two throwing arms, perfect for close battle encounters where you can cover a whole area to you left and your right while you are still able to fire straight ahead!

So after a bunch of tests and changing a few things, this thing is finally done.
The first thought 45° degree firing angle turned out to be way more to the side ( 65°degree).
It still does work very very well, with an effective range of 5 meters to each side. The CrossBBow is a perfect device for clearing rooms and hallways, lets say like in a hotel hallway for example, where there are doors to your left and right. You can easily shoot straight ahead while covering opposite doors on both sides of the hallway. Or at CQB and short distance, this thing should work reasonable well ;)

Additional things you need for this build:

Aluminium rod 6mm in diameter and 160mm long
6x M4x35
1x standard Airsoft AEG spring ( or alike)
2x M3x32
2x M3x20+nuts
1x washer with 20mm in diameter with a 8mm bore
2x 2x30mm nail ( with cut off head)
4x m4x30

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VA9hzWknhMA&feature=youtu.be

title: Board Fan and Led Button mount for Kossel Mini

description.text:
I needed to cool my printer electronics, because of overheating issues after installing a more powerful heated bed. I tested with a 40mm fan blowing air in from one of the sides and it worked, the board didn't overheat and stop in mid-print anymore. So I decided to take it to the next level and build a mount to get the fan inside the printer and add a more accessible reset button or kill switch on the way.

I'm using this button: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1477 which also adds a nice LED.

title: Rotating Table with 24BYJ-48 Stepper and 608 Bearings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a rotating table for a while and since I had that spare 24BYJ-48 Stepper Motor and Controller on hand (these come with various arduino starter kits) and a few 608 bearings I designed one for myself.

Since it came out quite good (smooth motion - not too loud) I´d like to share it with you.

The assembly is pretty self-explanatory:
Screw the motor into the base (cables facing downwards) using some self tapping screws around 3-4mm (be a liitle bit careful with the holes since the walls are quite thin - maybe I´ll rework them).

I glued the Base_Ring_Cover to the base - but it will work without glue too.
Insert 1 Bearing into the center of the Table and 3 into the posts using 3 of the pins - you can glue the pins or just leave them as is - that is far from fast so they shouldn´t come loose. If you need the Table_Cover_Ring you can print it and glue it to the Table.

For driving the table you´ve got two choices:

  • Either use the Spur_Gear and the Flat_Gear: Glue the Flat_Gear onto the lower face of the Table (where the bearing are) - it should center itself around the chamfer in the middle.
  • Or use Wheel and Tyre (the Tyre needs to be some flexible material) for a friction drive.

Why ? The Gears will make more noise - the Wheel&Tyre are quite. I´m talking whispering noise levels here.

What´s missing: Electronics mount below the Table - I´ll look into this and create a bottom for the Base which will be able to fit the arduino, stepper driver and a battery - but I need some time to source the parts.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

Non of the Parts needs support and has to be flat onto the print surface. I´m unsure if the parts are in the correct orientation.

Use enough top/bottom layers to make the surface (especially the Table) nice, even and non translucent.

I will finish the table with primer and white paint to smooth it out and make it non see thru (you can see the infill and the red base under good lighting for camera / filming setup.

If everything is printed in a non translucent white with enough top and bottom layers no finishing should be required.

comments.text: As for the electronics using an arduino uno seemed a bit wasteful since the motor only needs 4 outputs. i harvested the ULN2003 chip, capacitor, and 5 pin JST connector from the driver board and substituted the uno for an attiny85. this is where im at so far https://youtu.be/u_SHAWQKcmA

title: MeArm - Version 0.1 - Ultra Cheap Robot Arm

description.text:
This is the first iteration of the MeArm project. The objective is to build a very low cost robot arm for use in everyday tinkering and education. The BOM is a handful of M3 fixings, an A4 sheet of acrylic and 4 x 9g hobby servo motors. The idea being that it is simple to build and the most vulnerable parts are cheaply replaced. Inspiration came from the U-Arm kickstarter but the starting parts have more in common with the construction and simplicity of the Plot Clock. Available to download here to build your own or as a kit at our store in the UK
The Hackaday Store in the USA. MeArm is a Trademark of Mime Industries.

title: Kossel Mini Bottom Cover Plate Mount

description.text:
I cut a board of wood so that I could cover the bottom of my Kossel Mini, in order to prevent dirt from coming up, and keep the electronics isolated and therefore I designed this mount to be able to screw the piece of wood to the bottom of the 2020 extrusions.

3 pieces are needed to provide good support. It's also needed to raise the printer by 1 or 2 cm or more to have some clearance for the mounts and not have the printer sit on top of them. I'm using https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2202372 printed in TPU and it works and looks great!

Uses two M4 screws and sliding t-slot nuts (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01D83H10W) per piece.
Uses a M3 screw and nut to hold the cover in place.

Screw the cover first, then attach the electronics to the cover (optional) and finally fix the cover with the mounts.

Printer:

Modified Anycubic Kossel Mini

description.text:
My roommate requested I build something to hold his umbrella while he sits in his chair holding his tailgate location on campus. After 5 prototypes, this is the version I settled on.

The holster clamps onto one of the poles of the backrest of the chair (I tested, and you can't even feel it). The body has four slots for 1/4" hex bolts. I use wingnuts as fasteners for convenience. A previous iteration had the hex bolts embedded into the body, but I decided that was a bad decision after one print failed 30 hours into a 40 hour print.

This model was printed using HIPS from USAFilament.

This is a layout for making a 170mm high single digit LED display.  I use these to create the digits for my wall clocks.  10 standard 5mm (T1 3/4) LEDs are used for each segments (a total of 80 LEDs per digit).
I've also included a design for a small single-sided board that you can use to easily wire up your individual segments.

Cut out of wood or plastic, glue in LEDs, and wire up as appropriate.
If you're using the segment boards, populate them before putting them in the layout.  They're designed to run off of 5V, which is why it's set up as five parallel sets of two LEDs in series.  (That's why we need five resistors-- to keep the current stable.)  I run the segments off of serial-in current-limited drivers; use whatever seems easiest to you.

title: Filament Guide for IKEA LACK Table (with roller guides)

description.text:
I improved my own version of the filament guide for the IKEA Lack table.

This one has two rolls to guide the filament sideways. This prevents the filament from getting stuck at the end of the filament guide (particularly while printing large objects at a certain height).

This one is for 1.75 mm filament at the time. Let me know if you need other diameters, then I will build them for you.

Instructions:

  • PRINT THE PARTS AS THEY ARE ORIENTATED IN STL-FILES!
  • First stick the filament guide into a hole in the table (drill 10 mm diameter hole in the table top)
  • Then add the "nut" (make sure the larger ends point left and right! If not, losen the nut, turn the filament guide a bit and then tighten the nut again)
  • Place the two rolls on the 608-bearings
  • Stick the two 608-bearing onto the plate and place the plate on the nuts
  • Screw the plate onto the nut. You can use any screws that will fit through the hole.I use plastic-screws, but you can also drill bigger holes and take metric screws for example.

Changelog:
V2:

  • rolls thickened
  • the plate has two more srews to better stick to the nut
  • the chamfer on top of the nut‘s two pins was too big, it got thinner

2017-12-10

  • Added filament guide for 3 mm diameter

description.text:
This is a simplification of my combined bed mounting and piezo nozzle contact sensor https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1399512 and is shown in the sectional drawing. A 27mm piezo disc with a hole drilled in it is fitted between the bed adjusting nut and carriage. The piezo can be mounted directly on a flat surface on the carriage under a pad - this gives very low compliance; or it can be mounted on the ring abut without the pad, this method giving better sensitivity but more compliance. Many details on this and others on http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,635075,page=1
Two nuts are provided for 3mm or 4mm bed jacks. Glue or otherwise fix a nut, preferably Nylon or Nylock in the recess. Amplifier/conditioner DIY or from https://www.precisionpiezo.co.uk/shop
Take care drilling the hole in the piezo element, use a sharp drill and hold the piezo to a flat surface with strong tape. Drill 5mm hole for a 3mm jack or 6mm for a 4mm jack.. The ceramic powder may be injurious to the health, clean up the powder from the drilling operation.

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

dense

description.text:
Telescopic Cylinder, seven stages, with 45° stoppers, diameter = 80mm; 60mm, height = 50mm; 20mm; 100mm.

Telescopic structures are simple yet mathematically appealing. I was playing with telescopic structures and came to realize that the stoppers inside could be made from 45° angles for smooth printing. The design process (on Fusion 360, for example), is fairly easy. K-12 students could learn how to use variables (parameters) for flexible design, constraints for intended geometric shapes, and rotation (revolving) for 3D construction. This is an entry-point 3D design project, featuring structures that are traditionally impossible to make in one piece. The result, however, is aesthetically motivating.

Have fun!

Reference:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telescopic_cylinder

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

I was searching for a Filament holder that saves space and is compatible with every spool size. After some experiments I ended up with this solution :-)
The base of the filament holder is mounted to a top corner of the delta printer. The two rails can be slided onto the base plate in any position. The width of the base plate fits all spool sizes that I ever used (manufacturers should really agree on standard here).
The spool is mounted to two default skateboard bearings for each rail, ABEC does not matter XD

The type of required bearings is 608 ZZ. The dimensions are 8*22*7mm

In theory the parts should fit "out of the printer". Due to material shrinkage some sanding might me required. I printed my version from PLA and all dimensions fitted perfectly.

description.text:
This is a remix of the expandable ant formicarium by dantius. It can store from 500-600 to 20 ants. Don't worry about watering, the little lines in the walls will give ants water and humidity (put a little bit of water once a week in the cotton)

  1. Print

  2. Put acrylic or cut glass on top

  3. Put cotton in the slot and press it (not ultra-hard, you can break it)

  4. Put water in the cotton

  5. Cover all the exits with the "caps"

  6. I would recommend designing by yourself the entry hole for the tube

  7. Put ants inside very carefully or connect tube and wait for them to go in

  8. ENJOY!!!

(I know... the photo is really messy)

comments.author: enab

description.text:
After my https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2569919 I decided to design something more simple to print and maintain, so I began to work on it.
As you can see it has very few parts and make use of a Nema17 coupled to a planetary gear box 12.4:1 (https://www.youmagine.com/designs/differential-planetary-gearbox) that I already own, but if you don't want to print it you can buy a similar one on Aliexpress.com.
This way I can use it as per Lyman's winder v5 with minor modification to Makerel firmware.
I hope you'll like it...

All suggestions welcome!

Printer:

D-bot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

tried to make items printable without support, but in case...
Iìm printing all in PET-G but gears, wich I'll print in PET-G charged with graphite.

Refining...

Refine with great care the reducer gears and pinion-gear couple to achieve best results.

Very few stuff...
  • n. 2 F608Z ball bearings
  • n. 2 F625Z ball bearings
  • n. 3 F623Z ball bearings
  • n. 1 623Z ball bearing
  • screws M3 various length
  • M3 washers
  • M3 brass knurl as needed
  • M5 nuts and nyloc nuts
  • M5 washers
  • n. 8 M3x10mm flared head screw
  • M8 nuts
  • M8 washers
  • M8 nuts
  • n. 1 butterfly nut
  • 5mm rod
  • 8mm threaded rod for spool
  • 8mm rod
  • Lythium grease
  • GT2 belt or rubber band for spool axes coupling

All holes for nuts fit the 3mm knurled nuts, insert them with the help of a lighter.

Bearings:

  • insert the two F625 bearings into the gear support.
  • insert one F623 into each half of actuator arm, flange outside
  • insert one F623 into the filament guide lower hole, flange outside
  • insert thee F623 into the filament guide upper hole

Miscellaneous

  • assemble the gear box and let let it run with the Nema without grease until the noise decrease
  • disassemble the gear bos, wash well all componentr with alcohol and re-assemble with much Lythium grease
  • same two above operations for pinion and gear, then grease well

Oct 14

  • Uploaded new 8.stl (planetary box shell) modified to use 605Z bearing
  • Uploaded two new GT2 belt pulleys, erroneously I uploaded wrong one (GT5...)
  • Uploaded new gear support (wrong ball bearing size, sorry...)
    Oct 16
  • Uploaded new gear Gear_s.stl and pinion Pinion_s.stl, now with linear teeth, much more easy to print and refine.

• If someone, like me, has difficulties with Nema axis not aligning perfectly, I uploaded a further support with a 605Z bearing to solve the misaligning. Take a look at last picture showing it in place. You have only to drill two 3mm holes to fix it.
  • Also, for those don't like to spend hours and waste plastic printing the box and the spool support, I uploaded a new spool support Simple_spool_support_x2.stl requiring only an 8mm threaded road to keep the spool in place; the new support is fixed on a wood table which keeps in place all the other stuff.

As you can see, the base is tailored for my extruder but the components are the same; the rotation isn't so fluent, because of poor printing quality used, it's a prototype, I'll re-print gears when ready. title: Prusa i3 MK2 Spool Holder & LED Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are 2 very simple designs for Prusa i3 MK2. They probably will work for other i3-style printer if the Z frame is in same spec.

Spool Holder is designed to use d=8mm threaded rod. You can either put filament directly on the rod, or do like what I'm using (from: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:127181)

The max spool clearance is d=240mm "on paper", but it should fit most of filament spool without problem.

LED Holder is designed so you can have full clearance of max print space. It make it overhang alot but if you use light LED strip it should not be a issue.

All you need is double tap the LED strip to it :)

The MBOT DIY Plywood 3D Printer ( affiliate link: http://amzn.to/2zevNnD ) comes with a spool holder but did not have a filament guide which helps to keep the filament from dragging and pulling on the print head. This part will mount to the back of the printer using two existing holes. Add 4OD / 2ID PTFE tube from the top of this guide to the extruder (needs to be long enough to reach the front right corner of the printer).

(updated): Added the extruder guide tube holder modified from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2650720 for the 4mm OD tube.

description.text:
Slip on knob for Korg SQ-1 and Volca series. Dimensions based on the Davies 1900H series - 15.5mm height, 12mm diameter, 6.4mm ID. Top is hollow so you can see the led on the SQ-1 pots.

This fits very nicely printed in TPU and scaled down to 94-95% with low infill like 20%. In PLA it is an exact fit at 100% scale but might start to slip since it's not flexible. I've found that if you leave a little bit of the flashing around the bottom then they fit very snugly in PLA.

Note this is a fairly large knob so will work for every knob on the SQ-1 but is a tight fit on some Volcas where the pots are close to each other.

description.text:
A friend of mine was looking for an Advent Calendar so I thought it would be fun to try to make one. I wanted to be able to both make a 5x5 style box or a Christmas tree shaped box (or a cursor arrow if you like), to have space for a truffle or two, and be printable on my filament printer. The hinge parts will need to be slipped onto the door and then glued into the box. No supports should be needed. Read Luke 2 and remember the reason for the season that Jesus came to seek and to save that which was lost!

I have added some sample configurations.

I added a hanger hole to a box to help hang the design on the wall. Consider making one or more of these boxes with hanger holes to support the design on the wall.

I imagine for the Christmas tree configuration, painting the door handle balls different colors will look like ornaments on the tree. ;-)

Printer:

Geetech MeCreator2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Connect Door to box

To connect the door to the box, add the hinges to the door so that it makes a door and hinge assembly and then push the hinge assembly into the box into the hinge inserts on the box. They may be a little tight so you may have to push and wiggle them to get them in. You may not need glue but it might be a good idea to glue the hinge inserts into the box. (Being careful to not get glue onto the moving hinge parts).

Connecting Boxes

Each box should be able to slide in from the front or back of the other boxes. The connection should be tight so you may have to push and wiggle to get it in. You may not need to, but you may want to glue the boxes in place when you are sure of the configuration.

A simple catapult for launching coins, erasers and stuff.

I created this thing for teaching the process of 2D CNC milling.
The task was to set up the file for the CNC machine, including making required breakout links.

I used Rhino 3D to draw the plan, MecSoft RhinoCAM to write the program and a StepFour Xpert CNC machine controlled by Eding CNC Host to cut the pieces.

The drawing is suitable for 5mm material sheets and 3mm routing bits.

It's also possible to laser cut the pieces.

Printer:

Stepfour Xpert CNC Mill

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

3mm router bit

Notes:

3mm flathead router bit
2.75mm infeed on Z axis (2 cuts)
5.5mm total cutting depth
18000 U/min spindle speed
400mm/min vertical feed
800mm/min horizontal feed

This file can be used to teach and practice 2D milling.
The setup requires to layout the pieces, generating the G-Code, the setup of the CNC mill and of course the milling itself.

First prepare your material and set up a layout for all the pieces in the CAM software.
Then you have to choose the right tool for the job and preparing the file properly. The individual pieces need to be secured with breakable links, so they don't fly around while milling.
When the file is done, you can set up your material and the machine. Attach the right routing bit, secure your material and set your origin.
Finally you can let the machine cut out your pieces.
After the machine is done, remove the material and don't forget to clean the machine and remove the routing bit. With some sanding paper, you can remove the routing brows, before breaking the pieces out and assembling your little catapult. 
Have fun!

CAM software
CNC machine
3mm flat routing bit
5mm MDF sheet (or similar), 1 catapult fits on 1 A5 sheet
small rubber bands

  • CNC
  • 2D Routing
